transcript.speaker: interviewer
transcript.text: good morning, arun. welcome to the interview for the backend engineer role. how are you today?

transcript.speaker: candidate
transcript.text: good morning. im doing well, thank you. i appreciate the opportunity.

transcript.speaker: interviewer
transcript.text: before we begin, id like to give you a brief overview of todays interview. well be discussing your background, python fundamentals, and some backend-related concepts. lets start with your background. can you tell me about your experience as a backend engineer?

transcript.speaker: candidate
transcript.text: sure. i have around three years of experience working mainly with python. in my current role, i work on backend apis and basic database operations. i mostly handle feature development and bug fixes.

transcript.speaker: interviewer
transcript.text: that sounds good. lets talk about python fundamentals. can you explain the different data types available in python?

transcript.speaker: candidate
transcript.text: python has data types like integers, floats, strings, lists, tuples, and dictionaries.

transcript.speaker: interviewer
transcript.text: can you explain the difference between a list and a tuple?

transcript.speaker: candidate
transcript.text: a list is mutable, so we can change it, and a tuple is immutable, so we cannot change it.

transcript.speaker: interviewer
transcript.text: good. now lets move into data structures. can you explain what a stack is and where it is used?

transcript.speaker: candidate
transcript.text: a stack follows the lifo principle. i understand the concept, but i havent really used it much in real applications.

transcript.speaker: interviewer
transcript.text: okay. how would you implement a stack in python?

transcript.speaker: candidate
transcript.text: i think we can use a list, but im not sure about the exact implementation details.

transcript.speaker: interviewer
transcript.text: thats fine. can you explain the difference between a stack and a queue?

transcript.speaker: candidate
transcript.text: a stack is lifo, and a queue is fifo.

transcript.speaker: interviewer
transcript.text: have you worked with more advanced data structures like trees or graphs?

transcript.speaker: candidate
transcript.text: i have studied them theoretically, but i havent implemented them in my projects.

transcript.speaker: interviewer
transcript.text: understood. lets talk briefly about performance. how do you analyze the time complexity of a python program?

transcript.speaker: candidate
transcript.text: i know about big o notation, but i usually dont calculate it unless required.

transcript.speaker: interviewer
transcript.text: thank you for your honesty. do you have any experience optimizing code for performance?

transcript.speaker: candidate
transcript.text: not really. i mostly write simple logic that works correctly.

transcript.speaker: interviewer
transcript.text: alright. thats all the questions from my side. do you have any questions for us?

transcript.speaker: candidate
transcript.text: no, i think thats fine. thank you for your time.

transcript.speaker: interviewer
transcript.text: thank you, arun. it was nice speaking with you. well get back to you with the next steps.

transcript.speaker: candidate
transcript.text: thank you. have a great day.
